(23) Furthermore, if a person associates with wise and good friends, it can cause both their body and mind to be pure inside and out. This is called a true good man.

Excellent, you of the highest virtue, you have well explained the true Dharma,
The Buddha's teachings are heard by the ears and enter the house of my mind,
Causing my home to be peaceful and secure, and to serve as my protector.
I only wish that you will now listen to what I say,
Destroy my house of the deluded mind and break the beam of my ignorance.
Kindly drive away the yakshas who suck up merit,
And remove the rakshasas of various views, the thieves of delusion who make a jar,
The water of the view of the body is now full and has been destroyed.
The cow of deluded milk runs and breaks the fetters of ignorance,
The events seen before are all gathered in my body.
The various forms are like a mirror, with reflections appearing in it,
In the beginningless cycle of birth and death, I have never seen such things before,
Now, because of you, I have begun to see the four noble truths.
Now that I have met a good and wise teacher, the conditions come together and we meet,
Remove the affliction of greed in my mind, and drive out the ghosts from my home.
The four Vedas have long been transmitted in the world, saying:
One should perform a great sacrifice, adorning various things,
Preparing them on the sacrificial ground, with the great rivers such as the Ganges,
Bathing to remove faults and transgressions, one can quickly attain rebirth in the heavens.
I have practiced for a long time, but have never obtained the fruits of the path.
However, I am still unable to know whether I will definitely attain it or not.
Sacrificial offerings and ablutions are not as good as befriending the virtuous.
I now befriend the virtuous and have already attained the fruits of the path.
Not being born and not dying, liberated and heading towards nirvana,
Forever leaving the place of fear, this is not something sought through wealth and treasures.
Even if one uses the king's power, throwing oneself off cliffs or into blazing fires,
Severely in the cold winter months, freezing ice touching one's body,
In the sweltering heat of midsummer, the five heats are used to scorch the body,
And on top of that, one sleeps on a bed of thorns and nails,
Crossing mountains and oceans, worshipping fire and reciting spells.
Such ascetic practices cannot attain nirvana,
Only by cultivating meditation, wisdom, precepts, hearing, and diligence,
Such Dharma practices and so forth, from where can one obtain them?
Certainly, it is due to good and virtuous friends that one can then fully attain them.
(24) Furthermore, if a person commits evil and should fall into hell, encountering a good and virtuous friend can extinguish their sins and enable them to be reborn in the human realm or heavens.
I once heard that a person from Vakali went to Central India, and the king of India appointed him as the head of a village.

At that time, there were many Brahmins in the village. One of them, who was close to the village chief, spoke to him about the Ramayana, saying that those who die in battle go to heaven, and those who immolate themselves also go to heaven. He also spoke of the various pleasures of heaven, using skillful words to say: This must be so.
He then built a fire pit, piled up fragrant firewood, and held a Brahmin assembly. When the people gathered and came to the assembly, the village chief was about to throw himself into the fire.
This village chief had previously known a Shakyamuni monk. At that time, the monk came to his house and saw the various decorations in the house. The monk asked:
What are you going to do?
The village chief said:
I want to be reborn in heaven.
The monk asked:
How will you go?
He immediately replied:
After I jumped into the fire pit, I was reborn in the heavens.
The bhiká¹£u asked:
Do you know the way to the heavens?
He replied:
I do not know.
The bhiká¹£u asked:
If you do not know, how can you go there?
When you walk, you need to be guided and know the way from one village to another. How much more so is the long and distant road to the heavens?

The Heaven of the Thirty-three is 3,360,000 li above here. Without a guide, how can you reach the heavens?ğŸ”½If the heavens are blissful, why did that elder brÄhman, who is old and poor in wealth, and whose wife is also old and ugly, not take her along to the heavens?
What is there to love and enjoy?
At that time, the village headman, having heard this, thought to himself:
If jumping into a pit of fire can lead to rebirth in the heavens, then let the brahmins go with me.
Why is that?
Those brahmins are poor and destitute, with nothing to love or cling to, they should abandon suffering and seek the heavenly bliss;
If they do not go, they are just deceiving and wanting to kill me.
Having thought this, he then went forward and took the hand of the senior brahmin, wanting to jump into the fire together and go to the heavens.
At that time, the brahmin struggled and refused to go.
Why is that?
The brahmins came to the assembly only for the sake of money and wealth.
Then the village headman, seeing that the brahmins were unwilling to enter the fire, immediately spoke a verse, saying:
As heard, the heavens above have countless pleasures,
Touching things gives rise to greed and attachment, seeing east and forgetting west.
Calculating all the pleasures and possessions in the household,
Compared to the heavens above, it is like a mustard seed,
If you really have few desires,
and are without greed and attachment, I now observe you,
with intense and raging desire.
Looking after an ugly old wife, you come to this assembly,
seeking money and wealth to provide for your family.
If you love your son and do not wish to go to heaven,
consider the power of being born in heaven, which surpasses protecting your son.
If you do not know the heavenly way, why do you want me to go?
If you know the heavenly way, why don't you go yourself?
Why do you delight in teaching others, wanting me to jump into the fire?
Or do you covet my wealth, wanting to share it and use it?
Why are you so cruel and merciless?
Or are you an enemy from a past life, certainly a great deceiver,
Becoming companions with death, encouraging me to be reborn in the heavens.
Encouraging me to die, forcefully compelling me to enter the fire,
Forcing people to live far away in seclusion, practicing austerities.
Jumping into the abyss and leaping into the flames, starving oneself to show the cessation of eating,
Observing their teachings and intentions, wishing to bring an end to the family line.
These brahmins delight in killing,
Therefore I will abandon them and enter the Buddha's teachings.
The Buddha's teachings are of great kindness and compassion, never harming others,
A great fire burns the mountains and fields, the deer all flee in avoidance.
Because of their love for life, they seek out cool and refreshing places,
I should now do the same, entrusting my sincerity in seeking rescue and protection.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us saw that Vakkali's mind had already become disgusted with the brahmins, and deeply gave rise to faith and respect towards the Three Jewels, praising him, saying:
Venerable one!
You have now just entered the heavenly path.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½The Buddha's words reach the heavenly path
And the path of liberation,
These words are certain to reach, without error in between.
The path taught by the Omniscient One, with its distinctions of extensive and concise,
Harmless, truthful speech, giving, and subduing the senses,
This path and the heavenly path, are not attained by these austerities,
Throwing oneself into the abyss, jumping into the fire, and so forth.
This can lead to death, not the cause of heavenly liberation,
In the past, the lifespan of humans was long, and the lifespan of sages was also long.
Disgusted with this body, they did not wish to remain in the world for long,
First practicing various meditations, cutting off the bonds of the desire realm,
Knowing for themselves that abandoning this body, they would surely be reborn in the Brahma Heaven.
There is no way to lose one's life by throwing oneself into a deep pool or into a fire,
Because of losing one's life in this way, one is reborn in the Brahma Heaven.
Because of the concentration and severing of bonds, one is able to be reborn in the Brahma Heaven,
Not because of throwing oneself into a cliff or into a fire, one is reborn in the heavens.
There were fellow immortals who used the heavenly eye to observe,
Where did this one die and be reborn?
Seeing rebirth in the Brahma Heaven, first seeing the death by throwing oneself into a deep pool, considering this to be rebirth in the heavens.
The others, being foolish, do not see, considering throwing oneself into a deep pool or into a fire,
To be reborn in the Brahma Heaven, therefore giving rise to inverted views.
The other Brahmins, being foolish and lacking wisdom,
Do not observe the cultivation of concentration, severing the various bonds and afflictions,
But only see throwing oneself into a deep pool or into a fire, considering this to be rebirth in the heavens.
Because of this inversion and delusion, they subsequently give rise to various scriptures and treatises,
The foolish all believe and accept, throwing themselves into the abyss and into the fire.
The wise skillfully observe, abandon and do not engage in,
Cultivating all wholesome dharmas, taking them as the cause for the heavenly path.
Throwing oneself into the abyss, jumping into the fire, and so forth, are not the practice of wholesome conduct,
That can obtain the conditions for escaping death, nor are they the cause for being reborn in the heavens;
Relying on the Buddha's teachings with body and mind, this is called the path of quiescence.
What use are these non-Buddhist teachings?
Without results, one vainly suffers, drilling water seeking ghee, though laboring, it is forever difficult to obtain.

Furthermore, the practitioner of giving should avoid the eight perils. If one accumulates wealth and treasures, the perils and difficulties are very many. The wise person's cultivation of giving is then firm and secure.
I once heard that there was a king who punished merchants and told them:
All the wealth you have, show it to me.

The merchant went home and thought about the things he had given away before, the meal he had given to the beggars, and even the grain and grass he had given to the birds and beasts, and he listed them all for the king.
When the king saw this, he asked:
Why have you listed these things?
The merchant replied:
The king previously ordered that all property be listed for me, and these are the things I have listed.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The five families that share together are now all in the home,
The things I have listed now, no one can encroach upon.
Such things as have been listed, by kings, thieves, water, and fire,
All cannot encroach upon them.
Mount Sumeru and the great ocean, all will melt away,
But such things as have been given away cannot be burned by a single hair.
Money and property entrusted to parents, brothers, and sisters,
All close friends and relatives will eventually fail and disappoint,
Only the objects of one's generosity can never fail or decline.
Generosity is a treasure trove of practices, it always follows one through all lifetimes,
Generosity is the closest friend, nothing can destroy it,
The great ocean of poverty is extremely vast and terrifying,
Generosity is a sturdy ship, only the generous
Can reach the other shore.
I know the fruits of generosity, therefore I speak without fear, what is wrapped here is my wealth.
In the household there are treasures, shared by the five families,
Therefore I dare not wrap it up, saying it is mine alone.
The king, hearing these words, was delighted and praised,
Excellent!
You are a person of superior merit, I will not use any of your possessions now.
As you have said, generosity is your wealth, the rest of the wealth is shared.
At that time, the king spoke a verse, saying:
If one practices giving, with one's own hands passing it on to others,
One should give rise to a joyful mind, and not give rise to thoughts of regret.
Therefore, in future lives, one will experience happiness among humans and gods.
All the wealth and possessions, the eyes see one's own wealth and treasures,
Scattered and belonging to various families, unable to quickly give,
There is no one who can encroach and steal.
In the end, one will be taken away by others, with present evil fame and reputation,
In future lives, one will have much poverty and lack, this is the most foolish.
Seeing the houses of others, as well as their wealth and treasures,
After death, the family members use them, not a single hair follows oneself.
Seeing such things with one's own eyes, unable to give rise to aversion and disgust,
Quickly giving up wealth and possessions, wealth is not shared by the five families,
There is only the cultivation of giving.
There is no one who follows one's own, and one will definitely abandon them,
But one does not obtain the reward of giving.
The wise one should definitely give, both things are called giving,
One should give to oneself.
The fragrant oil always flows, such is the wise donor,
The benefits of merit are filled, praised by the people of the world.
Having wealth but stingy and not giving, one is ridiculed by the world.
Even if one has wealth and money, seeing a beggar one turns away,
Although one may have much wealth and treasures, one is called poor and suffering.
The giver, although poor, is always called wealthy,
The stingy one, although having much wealth, is not free from poverty and suffering.
The donor gives water, washing away the defilements of greed in the mind,
Stinginess has no good and joyful rewards, heading towards the path of death,
One will definitely fall into a deep pit.
When elephants, horses, cows, and sheep lose their vital energy and breath,
They all abandon it, and at the time of death, suffering and distress arise.
Because of this, there is attachment, and fear and great distress arise.
Those who practice giving are joyful at the time of death, without regret.
The stingy and jealous are criticized by the wise, while the generous, whether poor or rich,
Always experience happiness.
People all avoid and distance themselves from the stingy and greedy, even if they are present,
In reality, they are the same as hungry ghosts.
The wise are respected and admired by all, and are loved by the wise,
And after death, they are reborn in the heavens.
If there are those who love themselves, why would they not practice giving?
Giving is a good companion.
It is a supreme and wonderful provision, not using carriages, horses, or mounts,
Or all kinds of attendants and guards.
In the next world, it is a bridge, giving is free from many difficulties,
And the five families cannot encroach upon it.
Who, having love for themselves, would not practice giving?
Even if one obtains little in future lives, one should still practice giving,
Let alone practicing giving a little and greatly obtaining the rewards of merit.
Therefore, the wise should practice giving.
Furthermore, if one hears the correct teaching, one can understand the bonds.

I once heard that in the country of Taká¹£aÅ›ilÄ, a criminal was locked up in a monastery. During the night, the assembly of monks was expounding the Dharma. The locked-up person came to the assembly of monks and sat in order to listen to the Dharma.

If one is bound by form, this is called true bondage.
What is meant by bondage to form?
Seeing and regarding as upright, this is called bondage to form.

As for this form, in birth and death one does not know its root. In the great river of birth and death there is no place to cross over. One does not know the liberation from birth and death. In birth and death one is bound by all bonds, from this bodily bondage up to the next body.'
At that time, the one who was imprisoned heard this teaching and contemplated its meaning, remembering it without forgetting, reading and reciting it with ease.
Then the king sent someone to untie his bonds. His close relatives and followers, rejoicing in his release, all came to inquire after him.
At that time, the bound one spoke a verse, saying:
You see me untied from my bonds, and comfort me with joy,
But ordinary foolish people are always bound and never untied.
Form binds ordinary people, and the five aggregates completely bind them.
Birth can bind things, and death also binds in the same way.
From this life to the next, one is never untied and bound.
Revolving in the bonds, one repeatedly experiences birth and death.
I heard these words from that teacher,
And these words I heard with my ears were spoken by the Omniscient One.
All the afflictions bind my mind,
Like an ox bound by a yoke.
Not yet liberated from this, how can you all
Say that I am untied from my bonds?
If you truly love and care for me, you should inform the king
And allow me to go forth and leave the household life.
The other shore of quiescence and extinction, if one obtains such matters,
Then one can be called liberated.
If one can leave the household life, then one is free from bondage, truly attaining liberation.
At that time, the retinue, having heard these words, informed the king and then left the household life.
Having left the household life,

He looked at the doctor beside him and said this:

Alas, wealth and nobility are despicable and temporary, like a flash of lightning, like a flame quickly extinguished, like an elephant's ear moving and not stopping, like a snake's tongue constantly flickering, and like morning dew drying up when it sees the sun.
I have heard this verse from others:
Wealth and nobility are difficult to stop, fickle and not still for a moment.
The wise should know well, and not be arrogant or negligent,
In this body and the next world, one should seek one's own benefit.
If one obtains wealth and nobility, although one may be stingy and guard it,
In a hundred ways it will all be destroyed. Wealth and nobility still exist in action,
Like a snake moving in a crooked way.
If one observes well, when one is strong and healthy, one should quickly create merit.
If one encounters suffering from illness, one's mind should always cultivate merit,
It is not necessarily in the physical body.
If one knows that one will certainly die, although one may have wealth and possessions,
One cannot give freely.
If one obtains money through peaceful and beneficial means, and encounters a field of blessings, one should then quickly give it away.
If one is in good health, or when one is suffering from illness,
One should always practice giving, without any difference.
However, these possessions only bring about faults.
If one is about to die, even one's own relatives and children,
Although they are one's own possessions, if one wishes to use them to give generously,
They will be guarded and blocked, unwilling to give. In the midst of danger and distress, in an instant,
One's wishes are not free.

King AÅ›oka offered half an Ämalaka fruit to the Saá¹ƒgha of monks, and called a close attendant, saying:

At that time, the attendant followed the king's order, brought this half fruit to the monastery, gathered all the monks, bowed at the feet of the monks, joined palms, and said to the assembly of monks:

Moreover, using half of this fruit, I offer it to the assembly of monks,

At that time, the senior monks, having heard these verses, felt sorrowful and unhappy, giving rise to a compassionate mind. They accepted the half fruit and showed it to the assembly, saying:

Then he spoke a verse, saying:
The most courageous and generous one, the most supreme among kings,
The great elephant in the Mulian Sutra, named Ashvajit.

Now, for the sake of the ministers, he is restrained and not his own master.

Rich and powerful to the extreme, all have freedom to do as they please,

The foolish should observe this and quickly change their minds,

At that time, the senior monk in the Sangha said:

(28) Furthermore, if foolish people slight a wise person, the wise person will never give rise to anger, and when slandered by others, they will speak in accordance with them.

I once heard that there was a person who set up a guest meeting in his home, made many flower garlands to give to the assembly, and when the people in the assembly obtained the garlands, they all wore them on their heads.
There was a virtuous man who was extremely poor and destitute. He went to a gathering of guests and obtained a flower garland in turn. He did not put it on his head but placed it to the side.
The people all said:
This man is poor and wants to sell this garland, so he does not wear it.
At that time, the upÄsaka, having heard these words, replied:
It is true.
If I sell it, I will get a very high price, and then I will give it.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Like in the past, when I needed a garland, I once sold a flower,
For ninety-one kalpas, I enjoyed bliss in the heavens,
Today, in my final body, I attained the bliss of nirvana.
It is like the cowherd woman who used a foul-smelling grass flower,
Disliked by the crowd, the woman sold this flower,
And was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
I now wish to go to the Buddha, and also wish to sell this flower,
Able to give rise to such a mind, rare and extremely difficult to encounter.
Such a flower seller, incomparable in the three realms.
At that time, the people asked the upÄsaka:
Who can give a little and obtain great blessings and rewards?
Then the upÄsaka said to the crowd:
Now I will explain the Dharma of good and firm faith for you.
When a flower garland withers and dries up, one immediately discards it. The Buddha abandoned his royal status like discarding a withered flower.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The Buddha abandoned his status as a wheel-turning king, like discarding a withered flower garland,
The seven factors of enlightenment adorn his mind, pure and free from defilements.
With all adornments already complete, what use are these flowers?
I will only single-mindedly, with a sincere mind, offer a garland to the Buddha's stÅ«pa.
Now I sell to the Buddha, incomparable in the world,
Such a Dharma merchant leader will never have times of poverty.
This selling is the most excellent, with fame and merit,
I now hold this flower, wishing to offer it to the stupa.
Furthermore, it is like a magician using this aggregate body to perform various acts, able to cause the wise to see and understand immediately.
